Movie Tier List [Under Construction]

Published on September 1, 2025 | By JW

Here's a tier list of miscellaneous movies I've watched over the past several years (around 2020-2025). All ratings are absolute (not relative) scores out of 10. I am less likely to watch a movie that I anticipate I will not like, so the curve should not be normal in its distribution. In my ratings I usually emphasize plotline, cinematography/aesthetics, and meaning/impact, but frankly these are not as rigorous and consistent as I would prefer, and the standard for my ratings has shifted quite a bit over the years.

Roughly,

  • S: I would recommend watching and rewatching to everyone; a masterpiece
  • A: I would recommend watching to everyone; excellent
  • B: I would recommend watching to some people; possibly an enjoyable film depending on one's tastes
  • C: I would recommend against watching to most people; mediocre or forgettable
  • D: I would recommend against watching to everyone; poor with significant flaws
  • F: I would recommend against watching to everyone; minimal to no redeeming features

What trends do I notice? I tend to like movies that are cerebral and emotionally engaging. I like well-developed characters and plotlines, and I appreciate good cinematography. I avoid movies that were made more than a couple decades ago unless the visual qualities are not distractingly outdated. I prefer movies with unpredictable plot twists and endings. My favorite genre is thriller, and I will watch anything made by Christopher Nolan.

This is what ChatGPT thinks of my movie preferences:

You consistently rate highly (9–10/10) films that are:
  • Smart, twisty, or layered thrillers (The Prestige, Gone Girl, The Outfit, Side Effects, The Usual Suspects, Prisoners)
  • Intellectually ambitious sci-fi (Inception, Interstellar, Ex Machina, Arrival, I Am Mother)
  • Emotionally powerful dramas (Whiplash, Manchester by the Sea, Past Lives, About Time)
You often dislike overly stylized/pretentious films (The Master, Banshees of Inisherin, Sorry to Bother You) or gratuitous violence (I Saw the Devil). You’re lukewarm on some cult favorites (Blade Runner 2049, Drive, Inglourious Basterds), which suggests you prefer strong narrative drive and clarity over purely atmospheric or ironic filmmaking.
